ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I formed the knowledge about both neural networks and hardware implementations in this course.
This course covered the fundamentals of neural networks and learning systems.
I learned about different kinds of neural networks, how to implement them (sort of), and some new areas of research like hardware-software co-design and spiking neural networks.
Insights into the development and the state of the art works on neural networks. There is a substantial portion of the electrical engineering design for optimization of learning systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course combines hardware and software together. This is very helpful. 

The reading presentation made me learn a lot from other students.

The course covers a lot of applications in the first half, but then mostly becomes a survey of the latest academic papers in the second half. Depending on what you are interested in, you may like one half more than the other.

strength: good overview of neural networks
weakness: the psets could be completed without fundamentally understanding neural network architecture

It's not a time-consuming course, but the homeworks don't really prepare you for the projects. They're really easy and do teach how to implement a network if you do them in extreme detail, but they're so easy that you don't really struggle or retain anything afterwards. The research presentation could be better, some of it (the written report) felt like busy-work. The final project is really cool since you finish it with a paper that could potentially be ready for publishing. Professor Panda is also organized and cares about her students.

I felt like too much of the course emphasizes on the final project. I actually really appreciated the problem sets and the reading assignments, and felt like they helped me learn and showcase my understanding a lot more than the final project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course combines both software and hardware. It is really helpful to students who want to explore something new. They could balance their interests in different aspects.
I would recommend this course to someone who is already fairly interested in Machine learning, and wants to understand the hardware side of things a bit better.
Yes, if you have an independent project that requires neural network training!

Hmm probably not, unless you just want an excuse to do a project. If you're really interested in machine learning, there are other classes which will teach you more in-depth. If you have no machine learning experience and want to do a project, the final is good for that. However, you probably won't get too much out of the homeworks or some lectures. I think this class has potential to fill the more practical, non-math oriented machine learning niche at Yale, but it needs to commit to doing that and doing it well. It is nice to come out of the class fluent in the language of neural nets. Tbh I was (and kind of still am) skeptical of neural networks / machine learning, but this class convinced me there is value to the technique, both in application and in giving us insight.
